105.text:
On 2 February 1659, Major Lewis Audley was summoned
before the House of Commons for abusing two MPs.

153.text:

160.text:
'I have faithfully served you these 18 years and was

174.text:
So in this lecture, I'm hoping that we'll see

The experience of civil war and revolution,

190.text:
From the social, sexual and scatological slights

198.text:

206.text:

222.text:
From Oxford and Westminster it penetrated

227.text:

277.text:

It looks at peers, MPs, army officers and

294.text:
Let's start off with the nobles. Historians
have long considered that a majority of peers

300.text:

of social hierarchy. Yet in reality, much

308.text:
noble allegiance was murky, shifting and particularly
susceptible to turncoating.

315.text:
Very few English peers held military command
on both sides during the First Civil War,

320.text:
the war that ended in 1646, yet many travelled
the road between Oxford and Westminster, where

328.text:
the rival camps were headed, and they travelled
this road in both directions and on multiple occasions.

337.text:
Analysing noble allegiance is difficult as
their religious and political attitudes, concepts

342.text:

consideration as well as their personal relationship

348.text:
to Charles I and their concern for the safety
of their landed estates.

354.text:
For those holding land in multiple counties,
as many of them did, protecting their patrimony

360.text:

estates endured the depredations inflicted

367.text:

personal losses from continued warfare inclining

376.text:

Some even maintained rather self-important

383.text:

392.text:

448.text:

455.text:

and to liken Charles I to Christ.

2095.text:
The press were keen to print stories illustrating
the ghastly, or supposedly ghastly, ends suffered

2103.text:
by turncoats in order to deter others from
emulating them. When Richard Grenville was

2108.text:
wounded, the London press were eager to trumpet
this as a sign of divine providence.

2114.text:
One news book rejoiced that Grenville had received
a brace of bullets in his groin as a just judgment

2120.text:
of God because he was 'a notable whore-master'
and 'a notable prophaner of the Lord's day'.

2129.text:
Furthermore, the matter was conceived particularly
providential because he received this wound

2136.text:
on the Lord's day and in the West Country,
'where he hath hanged and murdered so many men.'

2144.text:
Another tract written, warning against the
dangers of backsliding was William Prynne's

2149.text:
'Doom of Cowardice and Treachery', written
in October 1643 to orchestrate support for

2156.text:
the forthcoming prosecution of Nathanial Fiennes
for having prematurely surrendered Bristol to the King.

2162.text:
This was a cheap and mass-produced
tract hoping to reach a mass audience of soldiers.

2169.text:
In it Prynne conflated the adjectives 'cowardly',
'mercenary' and 'treacherous', writing that

2176.text:
this was, 'an age of timidity and treachery'.
He concluded that exemplary capital justice

2183.text:
was required for those that betrayed their
trusts for the purpose of deterrents and to

2189.text:
make Parliament's officers and soldiers more
diligent and incorruptible.

2197.text:
Side changing was particularly prominent amongst
the pamphleteers and propagandists themselves.

2202.text:
In particular, four writers defected to the
King in 1647 from Parliamentarian or neutralist

2209.text:
positions. They were John Crouch, John Hackluyt,
Samuel Sheppard and Marchamont Nedham.

2216.text:
They produced Royalist propaganda, often at considerable
personal risk, until they were captured and imprisoned.

2222.text:
Nedham, Crouch and Hackluyt then agreed
to write for the Republic, whose propaganda

2229.text:
became considerably reliant upon former Royalist
writers.

2235.text:
Their defection invited particular hostility
from the Royalists. Anthony Wood called Nedham

2241.text:
a 'weathercock', 'valuing money and sordid
interests rather than conscience'.

2246.text:
Samuel Butler dubbed him 'a Mercury with a winged
conscience', 'the skipjack of all fortunes'

2254.text:
and 'a shittlecock' - I think that's a badminton
allusion there: whichever way you hit a shuttlecock

2259.text: it will land with the head pointing forwards.

2266.text:
Yet they changed sides to avoid hardship,
imprisonment and possibly even execution.

2273.text:
Historians are now uncomfortable with depicting
these writers as completely unprincipled pens for hire.

2279.text:
They were seeking to make a living
in difficult circumstances rather than amass

2285.text:
great fortunes, while their shifting positions
often correlate with fundamental changes in

2291.text:
the nature of the Parliamentarian and Royalist
causes.

2297.text:
So let's turn to honour, reputation and self-fashioning.
How did turncoats justify themselves?

2306.text:
Changing sides was deemed objectionable because it
smacked of putting personal interests before

2312.text:
those of the public at a time when gentry
concepts of honour stressed constancy.

2320.text:
Therefore, those changing sides sought to portray
themselves as having remained constant.

2327.text:
It was not they, but others, that had changed,
or even the cause itself that had changed.

2333.text:
Whilst they may have acted to protect themselves,
family and estates and to profit from victory,

2339.text:
nearly all denied such self-interested motives.
They frequently faced suspicions that they

2345.text:
sought to side with the strongest, so consequently
many sought to spin their past actions to

2352.text:
support a self-image of constancy, reliability
and untarnished honour. To do this they fashioned

2359.text:
constancy narratives to portray their actions
in the best possible light. These narratives

2366.text:
could take various forms. For example, those
written by Royalists coming to terms with

2371.text:
Parliament's courts tend to minimise their
Royalism and allege their faithfulness to

2376.text:
Parliament's cause from the outset. Propaganda
conversion narratives, in print, focused most

2383.text:
on the alienating features of the enemy whilst
memoirs and autobiographies, for posterity,

2389.text:
were most inclined to stress principle and
constancy. And also we have the wonderful

2396.text:
resources of some letters written by turncoats
themselves. The next volume with the Camden

2403.text:
Society, which should be published in the
next few weeks, is going to look at the Hotham

2408.text:
family's letters and these do much to reveal
the temperamental nature of gentry turncoats.

2415.text:
The Hothams were Parliament's governors of
Hull who had done much to aid Parliament's

2420.text:
war effort in 1642 but had harboured second
thoughts thereafter. The younger Hotham engaged

2426.text:
in a lengthy correspondence with the Royalist
General, the Earl of Newcastle, in which his

2431.text:
repeated self-justificatory references to
his honour strung Newcastle along and were

2439.text:
intended to protect his family estates from
Royalist soldiers until, prepared with strong

2445.text:
arguments against having broken their trust,
the Hotham family were ready to defect.

2453.text:
The Earl of Clarendon, the great Royalist
writer, was not alone among his contemporaries

2460.text:
in claiming that turncoats never prospered
and were never trusted by the side to which

2467.text:
they turned. A chorus of contemporary abuse,
for instance, greeted the eventual execution

2475.text:
of the Hothams, father and son, when they
were condemned by Parliament in January 1645.

2481.text:
I have here a picture of their executions
on Tower Hill.

2488.text:
Yet not all turncoats were shunned or executed.
Barbara Donegan has shown that the record

2494.text:
is dotted with turncoats who survived and
prospered. James Chudleigh, Bussy Mansell

2501.text:
and George Monck became highly valued by their
new comrades. Those able to persuade themselves,

2510.text:
and enough others, that they changed sides
from conscience might retain their sense of

2515.text:
honour and public reputation despite the bitter
condemnations from those they had deserted.

2524.text:
Both sides executed a number of turncoats
who were recaptured but after the King's execution,

2530.text:
the Rump Parliament's execution of turncoats
was intended to demonstrate the legitimacy

2536.text:
of the new regime. We met the Earl of Holland
earlier: he led a failed uprising in 1648

2544.text:
and was beheaded on Tower Hill. Colonel John
Morris, who betrayed Pontefract Castle to

2552.text:
the Royalists, was manacled like a common
felon, and then hanged, drawn and quartered

2559.text:
by common law at the York Assizes. He was
even denied a military tribunal.

2568.text:
Christopher Love, a Presbyterian minister was beheaded
for having assisted the turncoat Edward Massie in 1651.

2574.text:
And the Royalist sea captain, Browne Bushell,
was beheaded on the 8th anniversary

2582.text: of his betrayal of Scarborough Castle.

2587.text:
So these occasions ignited a lively pamphlet
literature, as you can see, that sought to

2593.text:
read meaning into the performances during
their trials and their personal demeanour

2600.text:
at their executions. The scaffold became an
arena for participation in political conflict

2606.text:
in a new way during the Civil Wars. Changing
notions of what constituted treason were asserted

2613.text:
and resisted during executions before large
crowds. Executions of turncoats were central

2620.text:
to this process because so many turncoats proclaimed
their own political constancy at their death.

2628.text:
Public debate about the condemned's behaviour
and their last speeches and the meaning of

2635.text:
their last speeches encompassed whether it
was more honourable to remain constant to

2640.text:
a transformed cause or to follow the concerns
of conscience in response to changing circumstances.

2648.text:
Competing interpretations of scaffold events
became harder to control as these execution

2655.text:
pamphlets proliferated. After the regicide,
the Rump Parliament was naive to expect that

2662.text:
Royalist hard men such as Browne Bushell and
John Morris would die a traditional obliging

2668.text:
death in which they confessed their guilt.
Rather they would use the platform granted

2673.text:
by their public executions to defy the regime,
prolong the conflict and mobilise Royalist sympathy.

2681.text:
So I would like to conclude now by saying turncoats
served a useful purpose. Many useful purposes.

2690.text:
One of which was allowing civil
war commanders to explain away defeats in

2696.text:
their self-justificatory memoirs. Fairfax,
Cholmeley, Hopton, Belasyse, Monckton and Grenville

2703.text:
all claimed that their defeats were due to
treachery from within their ranks rather than

2708.text:
accepting responsibility for their own failures.
This revealed something of the state of mind

2714.text:
of the defeated but also the urge to safeguard
their military reputations long after the

2722.text:
After the Restoration, those whose loyalties
shifted to navigate the troubled 1640s and

2728.text:
'50s with success aroused much resentment,
understandably, amongst those less fortunate.

2735.text:
Three such Pembrokeshire gentlemen were ridiculed
after the Restoration, quoting here:

2743.text:
'Roger Lort: of any principle or religion to acquire
wealth. Samson Lort: he can pray, as long

2749.text:
as there is profit. James Lewis: forced from
a Royalist to act as a colonel for the King,

2756.text:
loved more for doing no wrong than for doing
any good.' Ballads and broadsides mocked the

2762.text:
time servers of the republic as amoral opportunists
but reflected sadly on their success in ballad

2771.text:
and broadside literature such as this, the
'Turncoat of the Times' from 1665, which ends,

2778.text:
'For he that is wise and means to rise, he
must be a turncoat too.'

2785.text:
Prominent restoration politicians in the generations
thereafter acquired nicknames that scornfully

2792.text:
revelled in their inconstancy. Anthony Ashley
Cooper was dubbed 'The Dorsetshire Eel' for

2798.text:
his shifting loyalties. John Erskine, the
Jacobite Duke of Mar, was later nicknamed

2804.text:
'Bobbing John' for his political double-dealing.
Yet, as Melinda Zook has shown us, shifting

2811.text:
with the wind was more or less a national
pastime in Restoration England.

2816.text:
According to Jonathan Scott, the Whigs and the Tories
of the 1680s were, with the exception of some

2822.text:
hard liners, essentially the same people.
In time, many simply changed sides and this

2830.text:
was political behaviour learned in the Civil
Wars. Whigs were shamefacedly reconciled to

2838.text:
James II before abandoning him again in 1688.
The collapse of James's support that year

2845.text:
had its roots in civil war side changing.
When 200 troopers from the regiments

2851.text:
of the Dukes of Berwick and St Albans defected
to William III at a critical moment in November

2857.text: 1688, it had been expertly planned and executed.

2863.text:
Having lived through the Civil Wars, James
II knew only too well the fluid and unstable

2869.text:
nature of his subjects' allegiance. In this
way, Charles de Rémusat's observation of

2878.text:
post-Waterloo France might equally be applied
to England in the wake of its own civil war

2886.text:
and that is that, 'the public that scoffs
at the people who have served strikingly different

2893.text:
governments, forgets that it has done the
same itself.'

2900.text: I'd like to end there. Thank you.
